I recently had the privilege with the Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs Committee to interview members of the Australian Wheat Board and go through with them very carefully the arrangements that they have in place for the selling of Australian wheat.. I think we came away with the opinion that they were across the issues, that they do give licences to independent people who might be accessing some of these smaller markets to maximise the value, and that they are aware of the responsibility that is placed on them 9156 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 because of the single desk arrangement that they enjoy. But, at the end of the day, I believe it is in the interests of the majority, and probably all Australian producers, to see that they are in a very strong position on the world market. The United States of America has been mentioned in this debate and I think that we should say something about that because we are tied to the World Trade Agreement. The World Trade Agreement is certainly valuable because Australia does need to access markets across .the world. It is a valuable agreement as long as people honour that agreement. I have been very disappointed in recent days to see some of the actions of the United States of America. I am in no way surprised because we have seen them do this in the past. They are very aggressive marketers on the world scene; they certainly subsidise in their home production areas; and they use export enhancement programs to market around the world. They cause us extreme pain, in many instances, in these world markets. Because they are a major player, they have a major responsibility to act in a way that is responsible in world markets. It is disappointing, I think, to see some of the actions that they have taken in recent days to inhibit the importation Of products into their country. I note that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, has had something to say about that; it does certainly impinge upon the arrangements that we have. We are doing these things in good faith; we in Australia are trying to abide by the World Trade Agreement. We are trying to be good citizens and to have a free and open marketing system. I think it behoves the United States of America to act the same. I believe that even though my voice is not going to do much to the United States of America, we do have to speak up around the world about what we see as unfair trading. There is a little bit of suspicion in my mind when we see some of the debate on competition policy, because one of the things that worries me is that the debate is often driven by multinational companies. We must watch carefully whether the value that is being reduced on the producing side of some of these industries is in fact transferred across to the consumer. I watch closely some of those, and I start to question whether that is happening. That is one thing that obviously we, as parliamentarians, should be watching closely, because the philosophy of competition policy is that consumers should get a cheaper product. If that is not happening, then we have to ask ourselves, 'Who is gaining from this policy?' If the answer to that is that it is the intermediaries, the big companies, and the people who have the power to manipulate, then I think we should be looking very carefully at what is happening in that particular area. As I said, that leaves farmers in a very vulnerable position. These arrangements have been mooted for a long time. The industry has certainly worked its way through them. They set up a wheat industry fund to make sure that they had reserves available; the minister is now putting in place this enabling legislation so that the transition can take place; they will have reserves; and the industry itself will have control over its own destiny because of the way the structures are framed. In fact, with the A class shares, only wheat growers will be able to get A class shares arid they will elect the majority of the directors; they can keep control. Those shares cannot be transferred. That is very important; we have learnt that lesson in cooperatives in the past. That is a very important part of the whole legislation. As far as I can see, and as far as I have heard from producers generally, there is an acceptance that this is the right way to go and that there are great benefits in it. Thursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9157 'If the debate continues, and if people are still dissatisfied with this single desk arrangement, my orily suggestion would be for a dual desk arrangement and no further. A dual desk arrangement would in fact put competition into the marketplace. It could be a private competitor competing against the statutory company that we have at present or the corporate entity that is being formed. If there are some concerns about competition, it would inject competition into the marketplace as far as the buying of grains from individual producers is concerned. I think that most of the dissatisfaction is probably in the barley industry, not so much in the wheat industry. I know that there is quite a bit of dissatisfaction in the barley industry about the maximising of values in that industry. As I 'have said before, if there is total deregulation and if the individual growers have the responsibility to go out and market their product, they neither have the time nor the expertise to do that. If that were the case, I am sure that the big companies involved in the buying of grains across Australia would rub their hands in delight because they could then play one against the other, and they would certainly bring prices down, to the lowest common denominator. That is all I want to say about this bill. I congratulate the minister again. I do not believe that the amendment would add anything to this legislation. I believe this is the right way to go. Obviously, as the years progress, there will be more legislation following to ensure that the transition takes place. Motion (by Mr Sawford) agreed to: That further proceedings on the bill be conducted in the House. Family and Community Affairs Committee Report Debate resumed from 4 September, on motion by Mr Slipper: That the House take note of the paper. take note of the summary report entitled Aspects of youth suicide. I am pleased to note that I will be followed by my friend and colleague the member for Mallee( Mr Forrest), who is the chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. This report, a very small but very dynamic report, flowed from a very successful one-day seminar held in the House earlier this year. Experts in the field were able to paint a very accurate and very clinical picture of the trends in youth suicide: methods chosen by males and females; the differences in the success rates between males and females; the suicide ratecapital city, major urban, major rural, remote towns; hospital separation rates and death rates. It is all. very clinical and all very statistical. The information is there for us members to use as we. seek to compare our Australian figures with those from other countries. The second half of the seminar revolved around the support services provided by a broad spectrum of non-government organisations and was a general, broad ranging and very informative discussion on this very important issue. To my mind this was the key part of the one day seminar.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Quick (Franklin) (11.41 A.m.)
theText: '-I am delighted to be able to speak on the motion to9158 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 What did we find? Firstly, Australia has an absolutely appalling record. We are at the wrong end of the spectrum. Australia, the so-called 'lucky country', has a depressing, almost Jekyll and Hyde psyche when it comes to the issue of youth suicide. Evidence was given at the seminar about the complexities of youth suicide. We were asked: do we bring the topic out in the open? By taking this issue out into the light, do we encourage our at-risk youth to attempt to solve their seemingly· insurmountable problems by taking their lives? Will vulnerable friends of a suicide victim copycat the successful suicide if we focus on trying to work through the reasons why the young person took his or her life? As it states in the report on page 7: A major part of building effective suicide prevention programmes is recognising the major factors that affect young suicidal people. This will always be a difficult task, as the factors are myriad and complex and not always obvious to those close to a suicidal young person. That statement is the crux of the whole issue. It worries me and I often ask: why have we got to the stage where our young teenagers find it so difficultto share their feelings and inner fears with their parents, siblings, close friends, teachers or church leaders? Why are so many parents and extended families left wondering after the tragic death of their son or daughter, 'Why did they do it'? It is not just parents, extended family or the deceased peers who wonder why. The teachers who have charge of these young people for probably one-third of every day of their lives are also left wondering why they have not been able to pick up the signs and perhaps been al5le to intervene to provide the necessary counselling which might have prevented the tragedy from occurring. At the seminar, we were informed that there are some significant sociological factors that bear on the possibility of young people attempting suicide. As I read through these, I would ask the people to remember some of the things that have been mentioned in the papers recently. These significant factors are: firstly, a high divorce rate in the country; secondly, a high youth unemployment rate; thirdly, high female employment; fourthly, extremely high alcohol consumption; fifthly, a high number of unwanted pregnancies and, interestingly, sixthly, low church and religious participation. However, it is important to note that these factors are not of themselves the cause of youth suicide, but they are present in countries like Australia, which, as I mentioned, is at the higher and tragic end of youth suicide statistics. The seminar was told that events which can trigger thoughts of suicide and potential suicidal behaviour are: the death of a family member or a close friend; divorce in the family or some other major family upheaval; the break-up of a relationship with a boyfriend or a girlfriend; excessive use of alcohol or some other drugs; physical or. emotionall()neliness; confusion over sexuality, or rejection because of sexuality. And the last one was the issue of contagion: school friends or peers committing suicide; heroes committing suicide, and media reports of other suicides. These are the cold facts. The thing that concerns me most is the human dimension of youth suicide that faces our nation. I am sure .that all of us in this place can recount stories of young people in our electorate who have chosen to try and end their lives-and so many have succeeded. When I returned to my electorate last week, a constituent of mine, a good friend, related the story to me that at the weekend her friend came home unexpectedly and, as it turned out, Thursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9159 just at the right time. What did she find? She found her teenage son hanging from the ceiling. Because of her unexpected arrival, she happened to be there at the right time. She cut him down and was able to revive him and then take him for medical assistance. Governments of both political persuasions over the years have allocated considerable resources to try and tackle this problem. The Keating government allocated $13 million for the years 1995 to 1999 for the very successful here for life programs. The Howard government has provided an additional $19 million under what they call the national youth suicide strategy. Between them, these two programs have set up a series of services to attempt to address the issue of youth suicide-services such as follow-up for young people presenting to hospitals and health services following self-harm, and support for GPs and health workers to identify, treat and refer young people at risk of suicide. It is interesting to note on page 6 of the report that a survey was done by the Jesuit Social Services, and they found a very mixed result amongst hospitals, both in the Catholic and public systems. And it is amazing to me to read that some hospitals have minimal psychiatric and/or psychological care, and have actually discharged suicidal patients with no counselling or follow-up. That absolutely amazes me. If you had someone, for example, with a rifle involved in some situation of violence there would be immediate reaction and counselling and following up. But because a young person presents at a hospital with slashed wrists or a drug overdose, it is a matter of treat, discharge and you are on your own. Other hospitals have an established process when dealing with young suicidal people, including mental health assessments and appointments with youth workers and their GP. It makes sense. But why have we got this dichotomy between almost total rejection on the one hand and on the other a considered, socially responsible approach to these young people? In our report we made three recommendations which, to me; are pivotal to the government's response. Hopefully, once implemented by this government, and supported wholeheartedly by the community, they will result in Australia finally and successfully addressing this horrendous issue. We did something similar with the horrendous road toll in the 1960s, 1970s and early 1980s-and look how successful we have been since we adopted a national approach to the road toll. Priority 1, as we saw it, was to establish a national advisory council to provide strategic advice to the minister and the government on youth suicide prevention and related matters. The council should be responsible for creating appropriate arrangements for consultation and cooperation between governments and the community at state and territory as well as at federal levels. Priority2 states that a research advisory committee should be established to complement the work of the national advisory council on youth suicide prevention. The research committee will be responsible for advising the National Health and Medical Research Council on the management of research projects and research grants, and ensure consistency with national research priorities. Priority3 to me is the key to getting an immediate response. It recommends, firstly, the setting up a depression awareness campaign to educate young people and their support networks on how to recognise depression and get help. That is the key-recognising and treating. Secondly, it recommendstandard procedures for hospitals to adopt when treating a young person presenting with attempted suicide or self-harm injuries. 9160 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 Thirdly-and it has continued to amaze me since I have been a member of this House that we have not done this-it recommends ensuring consistency in data collection at all levels of government. I am absolutely amazed that this just does not happen as a matter of (;ourSe.· When you ask states, it is a mish-mash. Finally, priority 3 recommends an immediate review of current funding, and redirection of some funds to more appropriate and better targeted. programs. There are some excellent programs out there, but they do not have enough in the way of resources, despite the $32 million. Some programs are not working and need to be wiped. I look forward to bipartisan support for our recommendations and hope that our thr-e priorities are implemented by the end of this year. Unless we do, daily we will be hearing stories in our electorate offices of young people, in the prime of their life, taking their lives because of what, to them, are seemingly insurmountable problems. I am sure that my friend the chair of the committee, the member for Mallee, who is sitting opposite and is going to speak after me, will be dealing with the problems faced by young people in the rural areas. It is bad enough in the big cities. Once you get out into the small country towns, there are very few services and there are cutbacks by state governments of all persuasions in hospital and community services. If the services are not there on the ground, it is ridiculous to expect a young person, who probably is not of driving age, to access a service in a country town 60 or 70 kilometres away. They need the service in their country town. I look forward to the government responding as quickly as possible. Hopefully, by the end of this year we can have those three priorities from Aspects of youth suicide adopted and we can say to our young people, 'We are going to do something for you.' say, from listening to previous speakers and looking at the long speaking list, that there would not be a member in this House who has not been involved, either as a family member, relative, associate, good friend or parent, with this tragedy of suicide. I am really pleased to be following the member for Franklin( Mr Quick) on the speaker list and I am going to refer to the member for Franklin and me in terms of what is a key element in resolving this difficulty. The member for Franklin and I enjoy a good relationship. Somehow we have been able to find a way to bridge the dreadful political void that we often see and experience in the chamber. There are a couple of reasons for that. The mother of the member for Franklin lives in Nhill in my electorate and she reminds me very much of my own mum. WheneverI am going through I always like to drop in and have a cup of tea with her. She is always full of good advice. That is one reason. The second reason is that I am now elevated to the lofty status of chairing the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs which was responsible, under the previous chairmanship of the honourable member for Fisher( Mr Slipper), for conducting a seminar earlier in the year and producing the report which we are commenting on here again today. Attending that seminar and in the discussions we have had since, we are reminded again of the tragedy that families experience, having to go through self-doubt and questioning. Parents of young people especially go through the dreadful self-doubt of 'What did I do wrong? It must be my fault,' when very much of what occurs is a mismatch of a society that I think has lost its way a bit. I know the report speaks about every age group and in every age group the issue is awful. But my heart is with the youngsters. These are future Australians
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Forrest (Mallee) (11.54 A.m.)
theText: This issue of youth suicide involves us all. I wouldThursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9161 who somehow have lost themselves and have sought to end it all as the only option, when really; With the opportunity we have, they should be positive about their future. They should have facilities in their own sense of self-security to deal with life's difficulties. Nobody wants to pretend that life is not going to be difficult and that" there are not going to be crises to confront. For example, there is going to be the first time the most precious gem in your life rejects you at the age of 16 and wants to go out with somebody else. We need somehow to find a way to undergird our youngsters and warn them that this is going to happen and that dealing with rejection is something you need to develop strategies for. The thing that alarms me is having been close to where a young man committed suicideonly 30 metres from where I slept across the street; we were neighbours. People said they did not see it coming. I think that the clue to resolving all of this is to have some obvious triggers learned by people across the community because we are all going to be part of this. I support the member for Franklin's plea for complete non-partisanship in respect of this. I really appreciate the very positive way in which members have spoken already and their response to what our committee has put on paper and tabled in the parliament. I would like to make reference to my own 16-year-old daughter who last Saturday night brought home a friend of hers from school. They have developed into really good friends. I had had a busy week in parliament; if you remember what happened last week, all I wanted was a nice quiet night at home to relax and have an early night. But she was concerned about this friend who has already made three attempts to commit suicide. In a sort of desperate plea I said, 'Honey,I don't need this.' But we put the time in. We made an investment. Her attitude was, 'Dad, I just want to love this person. I love this person and I want you to help me help her.' If we can find a way to trigger that kind of caring concern amongst the school community and amongst the adult community, then I think we will all have achieved a great deal towards addressing the tragedy. The seminar provided a real focus for the preparation of the report. I do not want to focus as much as the member for Franklin has done on the alarming nature of the statistics that are presented there but we have to accept the fact that in the last 30 years the suicide rate for males has trebled and the suicide rate for females has doubled. I do not want to make that the focus, I want to make the solutions the focus. Our report very clearly, with a priority one rating, recommended: That a National Advisory Council on Youth Suicide Prevention be established to provide strategic advice to the Minister and the Government on youth suicide prevention and related matters. That will involve the whole community. I hope that the examples given by the member for Franklin and me might provide some lead. There have been in excess of 25 suicides in my electorate in the four years I have been the federal representative. My observation is that there has to be a caring, concerned group of people who have some insight into the body language and the emotional state that causes somebody to take this step. Those troubled people have to be embraced in a caring community, a caring environment, and they have to feel wanted and needed. It is as simple as that. It is not. complicated. It is not about spending millions of dollars on research and psychoanalysis; it is simply about ensuring that people feel that they are needed and that somebody cares about them. If they have an emotional crisis, whether it be the tragedy of losing someone they have loved, or the tragedy of being rejected by their first girlfriend, they need assistance. We have all experienced the latter. Infact, in my time. I have had quite a few. 9162 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 One needs some strategies to deal with that because rejection is something that human beings have a great deal of difficulty in coping with. The only mechanism to cope with it is if people have a sense of well-being about themselves, that they have a regard for themselves as being a person of worth, and that involves a view that can only come from inside a person, almost like their soul, so that they feel good about themselves. Even though somebody else might reject them, they know in here that they are of some worth. It is very much a relationship environment that reinforces that for· people. I saw it happening in my own home last weekend and I can only hope that I can play some part in the bigger picture to extend that very simple example from my own lounge room to the parliament, that we find the key. In trying to deal with 25-plus suicides, I have found that it affects everybody in my office. In fact, I have said to my staff, 'Do not take any chances if you get a distressed phone call.' On one occasion I jumped in my car and drove 200 kilometres to be there within a few hours, and I am glad I did. It was somebody who was feeling desperate, but all they needed was somebody to take action to share this terrible burden that they had. It turned out to be caused by a government department putting them under enormous, pressure, and it was ultimately resolved. We now have a very happy family there. It will involve us all. I am very pleased to hear the comments of members in this debate. This report has been on the table now for quite a considerable time. It gives us cause to reflect and see what other members are saying. I am very pleased to support the remarks of the deputy chairman, the member for Franklin, and I am looking forward to a very positive response from the government. I urge it to consider the recommendations in the committee's report; adopt them, and proceed from there. for Mallee( Mr Forrest) so lucidly and compassionately portrayed to the House. He shares the view I have that basically, whilst many solutions may be put forward to address the issue of suicide per se-both youth suicide and suicide by older persons-people have a strong desire to feel needed, to feel that they are loved, and to feel that they have some worth and role in life. If that can be addressed by greater one-to-one counselling, of the kind that occurs in sections of my electorate of Isaacs, primarily through the work of people like Andrew Humphreys, then I am sure that we will, as the member for Franklin( Mr Quick) has said, in adopting a national approach be able to gradually address this most tragic issue that blights our modem society. In fact, not only does it blight our society but in many ways it is perhaps one of the most difficult to tackle. The member for Mallee submitted to the chamber an analysis of statistics that deals with the topic that is both alarming and confronting. From a local perspective, the figures are indeed quite shocking. They are particularly concerning in the south-eastern coastal regions of Melbourne. Let me relate to the Committee figures for the Mornington Peninsula. The rate of suicide is more than twice the state yearly average amongst men. There are some 24.9 per 100,000 male suicides in this region each year, while the average for the rest of Victoria is some 11.2 deaths per 100,000. The picture in the Frankston area is equally as bleak. The number of men taking their own lives annually is 16.6 per 100,000-again, a figure that is well above the state average for the rest of Victoria. . In Cranbourne, where my electoral office is located, as at the end of July this year, nine young people under the age of 25 had committed suicide. This figure is triple the number of
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Wilton (Isaacs) (12.05 P.m.)
theText: I rise to paint a similar picture to that that the memberThursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9163 deaths that occurred in Cranbourne in the previous three years. The city of Kingston is a municipality that covers much of the federal electorates of Hotham and Isaacs. Suicide claimed the lives of 67 young people in the-city of Kingston in 1995, which is up from 45 in the previous year, 1994. While the picture on a local perspective is quite bleak, the story is similar at an international level. When recently reading the Victorian task force report on suicide prevention, I was most unsettled to learn that it is estimated that in recent years nearly one million people on this planet take their own lives each year. Suicide has consistently remained one of the top 10 causes of death in developed countries in recent history. While I applaud every aspect of the findings of this most worthy report; I disagree to some extent with the focus on the issue of youth suicide. The biggest group of people committing suicide in society is men aged 25 to 60. Without in any way demeaning the problem of youth suicide, it is clear that, from any objective analysis of the data, the risk to young men does not really commence until they reach the age of 19. I have referred to Mr Andrew Humphreys. Andrew is a youth crisis counsellor at the Chelsea Community and Information Support Centre and has been at the forefront locally of tackling the prickly issue of the high male suicide rate. Andrew points out that, while seven per cent of suicides are teenagers-and this is not an insignificant component-the biggest proportion of deaths does, however, fall in the category of men aged 25 to 60. An interesting point that Mr Humphreys makes is that the suicide rate for boys when they leave school accelerates, because that is the last time that they enjoy any form of day-to-day social interaction and day-to-day social support from friends or peer groups on a regular basis. From the extensive research that has taken place over the last five years, as this problem has been brought out into the open, it becomes apparent that, again as succinctly submitted by the member for Mallee, men kill themselves due to an inability to cope with life events such as relationship break-ups of the kind that both he and myself have suffered, and unemployment. On the topic of marriage or relationship break-ups, Mr Pierre Baume, head of the Australian Institute for Suicide Research and Prevention, is on the public record as saying that in a study of some 4,000 male suicides over 70 per cent were caused by relationship break-ups and men's subsequent inability to come to terms with the situation. Again as submitted by the member for Mallee, that is a time when men most feel alone, most feel unloved, and most feel that they have got no place in this world. Clearly, another major cause of suicide is unemployment. An Australian Institute of Criminology research paper into the causes of suicide has shown that a correlation exists between suicide rates and periods of economic turmoil. For instance, during the Great Depression Australia had extremely high male suicide rates. Another example of the effect of economic insecurity affecting the incidence of suicide was the 1987 stock market crash. In the six months after this event, suicide rates were up by 15 per cent. Other factors include separation from children, childhood trauma and learning disabilities. But as a rule, it is men who cannot talk about their problems, and there are too few services available to them-especially, as the members for Franklin and Mallee have outlined, in Australia's rural and regional areas. Men are often turned away by the all too few support agencies that are there to help, because those services are burdened with other cases. 9164 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October '1997 The discrepancy between male and female, suicide rates has increased during the last 30, yeats and; as those two members have previously indicated, this difference is greatest in rural areas; The overall ratio between males aildfemale suicides is' four to one; and the youth ratio is Jive to one. Men in particular have nowhere to go. Access to counselling services' which have a specific focuspn combating the propensity for rpale suicide-s sadly lacking, and this needs to be addressed. The way social supports have been dramatically improved over the last 20 years for battered womenprbvides a good blueprint for what needs to be done. We must tailor our community support services to tackle specific problems, rather than trying a sweeping, 'broad brush; generalised approach, which will inevitably mean that many seeking help will feel alienated. Some quite urgent changes do need lobe made if we are to cut the number of self-induced deaths in our society, especially amongst the most vulnerable in our ,society , those being males. We must extend counselling services within our community to target groups that are not being serviced, and I suggest that tharis primarily men in the 25 to 60 age bracket. As an extension of this, it is important that we up-skill social, workers in appropriate assessment and counselling techniques, which have been so sadly lacking in the past. "There must be greater education for both doctors and health service providers within the community about the risk factors which can lead to suicide amongst older men. As theniember for Mallee has said, this does not mean ,thar we embark on huge psychoanalytical research papers as to whY these things happen' That is not needed. Doctors rieed to be trained in skilling themselves as to, why these events occur, based on people's lack of self-worth at the times at which they are most likely to take their own lives. Among the lesser known statistics about suicide in Au strali a are the high levels committed amongstolder men between the ages of 65 and 69. In 1995, there were 15.2 deaths per 100,000 people for men and 3.27 deaths per 100,000 people for 'women. It is important that, as an institution, parliament should take a closer look at the hidden' categories of suicide in Australia. The fact is that until we, as, a society, are open" and informed about suicide in the most vulnerable of categories-again amongst older males-the pattern of death will no doubt continue unabated. A positive aspect to the debate about youth suicide is that we are probably much more capable of tackling this tragedy on, a natiomil basis, as the member for Franklin has quite rightly submitted, now that the problem is dut in the open arid that people are rightfully aware of it. Ilis to be hoped that in this country such an enlightened apprOach can now be extended to other forms of suicide which are perhaps less readily acknowledged. While it is perhaps a little too early for'extensive statistical evidence to be processed, the anecdotaL evidence that! have received froih people in my electorate is that theincreasing focus on gambling in Melbourne has led io'fim'tncial problems, in marly families. Sometimes the tragic consequences of these strains has resulted in suicide. Figures released by the coroher's office reveal that the number of gambling related suiCides has steadily increased since ,1992. It is of concern to me that,while over $1 billion is flbwing into the state government coffers in Victoria from gambling'revemie each year, only about $40 million has beeI1 spent on problems with gambling services over the last five years. If we are to tackle the incidence of suicide in society, the issue of problemganibling' must be addressed. I applaud and welcome with open arms the fine efforts of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs and its summary report on aspects Thursday, 2 October .1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 9165 of youth suicide. I am hopeful that the positive work done by the committee in forma1isinthis report will act as a catalyst for more research into the various other aspects of suicide which, to date, have not been given the amount of attention that I would suggest they so rightfully deserve. While some factors which lead to suicide are quite hardto quantify, there is certainly a need for our community to work towards an environment in which people feel a sense of belonging and meaning, as the member for Mallee has hit upon so accurately. If we can achieve such a state, then the incidence of all suicides-young or old, male or female-will no doubt be reduced. Unfortunately, it is very hard to create a sense of belonging for people that transcends individual needs and material things in a society which is increasingly obsessed with individual self-advancement and the attainment of material goods. I just conclude by stating .that, if we can tackle some of the fundamental problems in society, such as the quality of education, unemployment and job security, then there will no doubt be a flow-on to reduced family breakdowns and, by extrapolation, fewer suicides. Unless we as a society can tackle the fundamental problems and causes of angst in a way that the member for Mallee has suggested, then all the programs in this world and all the heartfelt words of compassion from politicians like the member for Franklin and the member for Mallee will indeed not change a thing. Dr SOUTHCOTT (Boothby) (12.19 p.m.)-I rise to speak about the seminar that was held here earlier this year; which I attended representing the Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge). The symptoms of depression have been recognised since antiquity. The Old Testament describes King Saul suffering from a depressive illness and Homer's Iliad gives us the story of Ajax's suicide. Hippocrates actually used the terms 'mania' and 'melancholia' to describe mental disturbances and other Roman physicians like Celsus and Galen also discovered melancholia. In fact, some of Durer's woodcuts dealt specifically with the subject of melancholia. Closer to home, in Australia, those who are familiar with Michael Leunig's excellent cartoons will have seen often that a lot of them actually depict depression. He will often have one of his characters in a small, dark room with a tiny window with justa little bit of light coming in. About five years ago, I heard Michael Leunig speak at the art gallery in South Australia. He talked then, amongst other things, about youth suicide and about how, particularly in Perth, there had been a cluster of suicides that had occurred at one of the private schools there. He described his own sufferiQg that he had had with depression and how. it had translated into his work. It has often been noted that Australia has one of the highest youth suicide rates in the world; and it is truly atragedy that suicide occurs as commonly amongst 15to 24-year-olds as does death resulting from motor vehicle accidents. Thirty years ago, no-one would have ever believed that the number of deaths from motor vehicle accidents would be almost the same as that from youth suicides. What has happened is that a very efficient public health strategythrough changing people's behaviour with the wearing of seat belts, with random breath testing anq with checking people's speeds-has led to a change in behaviour and a rapid decline in the number of 15to 24-year-olds who die in motor vehic1e accidents. Unfortunately, we have also seen a two to three times increase, since 1970, in the number of young males who are killing themselves. 9166 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 As far as suicide attempts go, there are almost equal numbers between male and female, but the attempts by young males are often more successful; something like nine times as many young males will actually successfully complete suicide as opposed to females. For every successful suicide attempt, there is something like 40 to 100 unsuccessful bids. What is particularly significant about that is that the No. 1 predictive factor-more than any other factor-of whether someone will actually commit suicide is a previous suicide attempt. Why do we lead the OECD in youth suicide rates, and why is it particularly high in rural and regional areas amongst our indigenous population? The reasons people attempt or commit suicide are unavoidably complex. While certain sociological influences and mental health background are factors, often the family and friends of the people who commit suicide just cannot recognise what the catalyst was that caused their friends to take their own life. As the speakers in the seminar highlighted, mental health problems and sociological factors can combine to induce a severe state of depression which, if undetected and untreated, may result in suicidal behaviour. One of the real tragedies of youth suicide is that this depression is completely treatable. The real tragedy is that often the depressive symptoms are not detected and not treated. The cost that that imposes on us as a society is that we are losing part of a cohort of Australia's future. Professors Cosky and Goldney, in a 1994 study, found that 90 per cent of people who actually committed suicide had evidence of psychiatric illness beforehand. One of the advances that I think we could see in public health would be people being able to recognise the symptoms of depression in their family members, and friends recognising symptoms of depression. Often it is very hard, especially amongst adolescents, to know what is normal adolescent behaviour and what is actually depressive behaviour. Amongst adolescents, depressive illness can be manifest in things like poor academic performance. It can be manifest in drug abuse, antisocial behaviour, sexual promiscuity, truancy and running away. They are all some of the symptoms of depression amongst adolescent children. A mnemonic to remember the symptoms and signs of depression which I was taught at medical school was 'in sad cages'. That was a very useful way of remembering how people manifest with depression: 'i' was for a loss of interest; 's' was for suicidal ideation; 'a' was for appetite-they often have disordered appetite or complete loss of appetite; 'd' was for depression; 'c' was for lack of concentration; 'a' was for affect-their whole mood was blunted; 'g' was for feelings of guilt; 'e' was for energy; and's' was for suicidal ideation. One of the greatest advances in the area of mental health will be when people recognise it, just as people recognise that when they have chest pain it is a good idea to get to a hospital as soon as possible or that if they are passing too much urine they may have diabetes. It would be useful if people realised that, if their appetite and sleep are disordered or if adolescents are particularly antisocial-perhaps more than normal-it may be something that is treatable without any sort of stigma. Countries with high youth suicide rates-and the member for Isaacs( Mr Wilton) touched on this-have exhibited sociological factors such as high divorce rates, high youth unemployment, excessive alcohol consumption and low religious participation levels. Perhaps all of those could categorise Australia. They also apply to New Zealand, Canada and northern Europe. What we actually need in Australia is a coordinated program which includes things like primary prevention activities. They are just activities focusing on having a healthy school Thursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9167 environment and on having strong families that actually encourage and nurture the individuals within them. Another area is media strategy. One of the problems with the reporting of suicides in the media is that it has been shown in research that it leads to an increase in suicide rates, especially if there are reports of, say, the hopelessness of people who commit suicide or the method used for the suicide. What is actually needed is for the media to focus on how treatable the depressive and sociological factors can be and also how these people can get help. Other programs could involve: restricting access to the methods; such as firearms, particularly common in rural areas; school based programs; targeted intervention for high risk individuals-those individuals who are already displaying symptoms of mental illness and those individuals who have already actually attempted suicide-and professional training for all health professionals, including medical practitioners, so that they are able to recognise who is at risk from suicide and who needs follow-up after an episode of self-injury or suicidal behaviour. In addition, personal events which may appear insignificant to the outside world can often have a huge impact on young people and can trigger suicidal thoughts or behaviour. Those personal factors can include: the loss or death of a family member or friend; major family upheavals such as divorce or remarriage; relationship break-ups with boyfriends or girlfriends; isolation from other people both physically-a problem in rural and remote areas-and emotionally, such as having few friends or.low social skills; excessive use of alcohol or other drugs; confusion over sexuality or rejection because of sexuality; and contagion-that is the idea of media contagion where you are surrounded by either friends who suicide or rock band heroes such as Kurt Cobain of Nirvana or media images of people who have committed suicide. It is worth noting that copycat suicide is not a new phenomenon. Two hundred years ago, Goethe wrote a book, The Sorrows of Young Werther, which was about a young German' hero who did commit suicide. That book was banned in several European countries after young men across Europe were killing themselves either dressed in the manner of Young Werther or with the page in the book open at the part where he killed himself. What is modern, however, is the concern that is shared by counsellors, youth workers and researchers alike, that suicide is becoming a more acceptable problem solving option in our society, a notion which is reinforced by media coverage and television and film dramatisation. At the seminar, Associate Professor Pierre Baume pointed out the large amount of information on the Internet on how to commit suicide. There is not much we can do about actually controlling the information which is on the Internet, but it is important that that negative information on the Internet must be also counteracted by positive information about the .early intervention or' treatment· of depression. One project which was just recently launched at Flinders University in my electorate of Boothby deals with the early identification and treatment of mental health problems in children and young people, and that project will-be jointly managed by Dr Graham Martin of Flinders University and Professor Bob Cosky of the University of Adelaide, who was one of the participants in the seminar. Funded urider both the national mental health strategy and the national youth suicide prevention strategy, AusEInet II will establish a national communications network to provide information to services, researchers and policy makers in this area. It will also develop best practice models of early intervention for the mental health of children 9168 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 and young people. Divided into three streams, AusEInet will focus on research, reorientation. and relevance. Having spoken with both Dr Martin and Professor Cosky, I am confident that a networkwill·· be established which will have national coverage to make sure that as many people as possible working in this area will have access to the information. Particularly encouraging is that the outcomes of the national youth suicide prevention strategy projects will also be disseminated through a clearing house set up under AusEInet II. Youth suicide is an ongoing tragedy in Australian society. I commend the organisers for the aspects of youth suicide seminar for addressing this problem and granting it the urgency and· importance that it deserves. . at Cessnock's John's Anglican Church for 21-year-old Jason Bambach. Jason had taken his life the Saturday night before. As is usually the case, Jason appeared to have the world at his feet and appeared happy. He was a gifted footballer who, lam advised, had been approached by the Newcastle Knights. Typically, what went wrong in Jason's mind will probably remain a mystery. My sympathy goes to Cessnock's Jack and Kay Bambach and theiffamilies. Jason Bambach is likely to be just one of more than 400 15to 21-year-olds who will commit suicide in Australia this year. Many more of course will fail in their attempt. Most of those 400 or more have been, or will be, on a proportional basis, from rural and regional Australia-just like Cessnock's Jason Bambach. There are now three times more young males committing suicide in Australia than was the case in the 1960s. For young females the number has roughly doubled. One of the great mysteries for me is why the suicide rate in Australia appears higher than compared with other developed nations. What does not surprise me is that so many suicides occur in rural and regional Australia. The Commonwealth spends more than $30 million annually on youth suicide prevention. Much of that money goes to the national youth suicide strategy, which has allocated some $6 million over three years for rural and regional youth counselling services; $6 million to Lifeline and the Kids Help Line; some $3 million for parental programs developed by the Department of Health and Family Services; some $2 million for the education and training of professionals, such as doctors and other health workers, and school teachers; and $1 million over three years for child mental health research, which is designed to at least attempt to determine the factors that lead to suicide amongst our youth. But while I commend the commitment of both sides of parliament, both the present government and the former Labor government, to the funding of these programs, in a senseand I do not say this disparagingly-all but the last of the allocations I mentioned is somewhat reactive in its nature. They are commendable, appropriate and essential, but they are somewhat reactive. We will only begin to make ground against this terrible social ill when we get on top of the larger economic issues in this nation. Chief amongst those is unemployment and economic decline in rural and regional Australia, which, in large part, indicates why youth suicide is higher in rural and regional Australia than is the case in our metropolitan areas. People in rural and regional Australia are continually told that trade liberalisation, competition policy, financial deregulation and privatisation are all good for them. If that is true, and if it is true that all of those reforms lead to higher or faster economic growth, those living in rural and regional Australia are entitled to ask: where is our dividend? Whereis the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon (Hunter) (12.31 P.m.)
theText: At 1.30 p.m. last Thursday a funeral was heldThursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9169 additional commitment to infrastructure projects which create jobs in rural and regional Australia? Where are the greater transport and telecommunications links? These are communities which are dying. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I know that in your own area, in Coffs Harbour and surrounding areas, the unemployment rate is very high, as is the case in the lower part of my electorate. These communities are experiencing what the experts describe as dynamic decline. It is a vicious circle, usually precipitated by the withdrawal of a reasonably large industry in the town or, indeed, the withdrawal of a government department or the withdrawal of a bank. The withdrawal leads to job losses. Family incomes decline as a result. Consumer spending falls. Other businesses in tum close and further jobs go. Those who can afford to, or who have the ability to, exit the town. Those who are aged or infirm, or who do not have any job prospects in metropolitan Australia, in the cities, remain. The largest industry in the community becomes the local social security office-and even they are now going as well. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report titled Aspects of youth suicide is a good report, one that I am sure will go a long way to addressing this terrible social problem. I congratulate the committee on the establishment of the forum held in February. I enjoyed reading the report which came from it. But a comfortable society is a working society, and a greater commitment to jobs by government in this country must come now. It is now not just desirable; it is essential. Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs with a great deal of interest. Obviously the problem we have in our country with youth suicide is a very serious one indeed. This report, and the seminar which led to it, is a very worthwhile contribution to our understanding in this country of the serious nature of the problem that we face. Unfortunately, as with many of the serious problems we have in our country, it seems to me that we talk a lot about them without actually doing much about them. What we seem to do is to talk about what the problem is and then very often seek to rationalise it or put bandaids on it, rather than getting to the fundamental causes of the problem and doing something about it. I suspect-and I am not trying to be unkind,. because I really do believe this is a valuable contribution-that already we have seen a reaction to this report and to the problem that again seems to me to some extent to be not getting to the fundamental causes of the problem. We have a national youth suicide prevention program in place which will result in the expenditure of a large amount of money. It seems as though the reaction to a problem often is to spend a lot of money on it, and the more money you put into it somehow that is a greater recognition of the extent of the problem. The solution to some of these problems is money. The solution to many problems is resources, and that certainly has been the reaction to this problem, with a strategy that allocates millions of dollars to rural and regional youth counselling services, millions of dollars to Lifeline and Kids Help Line, millions of dollars to programs for parents, millions of dollars for a youth suicide prevention and education and training program and so on. I am not condemning that expenditure of money, and it may be helpful. I am sure it could be demonstrated that those things are going to be helpful, but the point is that this report very clearly identifies the causes of the problem. I think Associate Professor Baume's contribution was a very worthwhile one. I know him and I believe the work that he does in this particular
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Bradford (Mcpherson) (12.38 P.m.)
theText: I read the report of the House of9170 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 area, particularly his desire to establish a national approach to the collection of data, is very worthwhile. He identifies in his contribution the causes of the problem, and these are they: a high divorce rate, high youth unemployment, high female employment-that is interesting and I will deal with each of these in turn-extremely high alcohol consumption, a high number of unwanted pregnancies and low church or religious participation. The first problem that Professor Baume identifies is a high divorce rate. I just want to note that. An article came across my desk yesterday which summarises the extent of that problem as well as any other document. The number of divorces in Australia has quadrupled over the past 20 years. Last year, Australia had the highest divorce rate since no-fault divorce laws were introduced in 1976. We have also recorded the lowest number of marriages per capita this century. Last year, Australia had the third highest divorce rate in the world, 2.9 per 1,000 people, just behind America with 4.6 and the United Kingdom with 3.0. If we acceptProfessor Baume makes the point and I think the report reinforces it-that there is a correlation between youth suicide rates and divorce rates, then part of the answer to the problem obviously is to look at the problem of divorce in Australia because it is such a big problem. When we look at what we are doing about that, one wonders whether our response to that problem is strong enough. At the moment we are talking about making some changes to the Child Support Agency. They are long overdue for those who have been dealing with that particular bureaucracy for a long time. But, again, in a sense they are not the solution to the problem. The Child Support Agency's problems are a product of the high divorce rate in Australia. Even with the wisdom of Solomon, it has become evident to those who have confronted this problem over the years that it is almost insoluble. Ironically, it was Solomon who demonstrated his wisdom, as I recall the story; in the first place by dealing with a custody problem-and his solution was to cut the child in half. Of course, that in a sense solved the problem. I will not go into the story because there is probably not the time here this morning for bible stories. But it is instructive. We have a problem with divorce, which then leads to our problem with the Child Support Agency bureaucracy. If we did not have the huge divorce problem then we would not have as many problems as we have in picking up the pieces. The problems associated with the level of divorce in Australia can be solved, and that is where our emphasis ought to be. I am not going to speak at great length about that today. It is something I have spoken about quite a bit in the past, but we have to look at the law. As I said earlier, since the no-fault divorce law was introduced in 1976, we have had this huge escalation, this quadrupling, in the amount of divorce. I am not going to argue here, and nor have I argued in the past, that we wind back the clock to pre-1976, but we have to recognise that since 1976 we have got this problem. We are dealing with that particular fact. It has occurred largely because we have made divorce too easy. I recall Archbishop Hollingworth in Brisbane being asked once what he would do about the problem, and his response, when he thought about it for a moment, was very good. He said that he would make marriage more difficult to get into and more difficult to get out of. That is part of the solution to divorce. Lest colleagues opposite, or even on my side, start getting excited, as some of them do, and particularly some of our female colleagues who are of that bent, and say, 'What you want to do is get more women chained to the kitchen sink and be subservient to their husbands', and all that sort of garbage that we hear trotted out when you make these sorts of suggestions, the Thursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9171 fact is that it is too easy for people in the current situation to simply walk away from a contract that is entered into solemnly. No other contracts can be walked away from so easily. We enter into commercial contracts that have sanctions attached, and important as they might be, they are not as important as a life contract that involves the care and nurture of children, in most cases. Despite that, people can suddenly decide today, 'I'm tired of this relationship; I want to find the new me; I want to experience new horizons', and so out the door they go. The CSA is knocking on the door the next day and, of course, it is all downhill from there. There is a connection between high divorce rates, as Professor Baume points out, and the high rate of youth suicide. When we understand that fact and look at all the counselling services, all the millions of dollars that we are expending on worthwhile things, as they might appear to be, we will come to understand that money will not solve the problem. We need to get to the core of the problem in our country and realise that marriage as an institution needs to be revitalised and that we need to re-establish the importance of it as a fundamental relationship. We need to stress the importance of families, which is something I speak about in this place quite often, as the fundamental unit in our society . We need to start supporting marriage and placing value on it and making it more difficult for people to walk away from without sanction. That is the underlying thing. You talk about a contract. This is a relationship you can walk away from without any sanctions. It is not a question of who has caused the problem. I am not arguing that we go back to the days before no-fault divorce law, but I am talking about people accepting responsibility for their actions. In this particular case there is no responsibility accepted for people's actions. There can be a lot done to reduce the rate of divorce in this country. It is often observed that we also make it very easy for people to get married. I suppose the law reinforces the view that 'We will give it a go. If it does not work, then under the law we can just walk away,' which is no way to enter into such a solemn and important and fundamental contract. That is why there is the need to make sure people understand, through the benefit of premarital counselling and other such opportunities, the importance of what they are doing. I will make a point that I have made before: just look at how much money we spend picking up the pieces after divorce. We spend billions of dollars, one way or another, picking up the pieces after a divorce, whereas we spend so little at the front end, on educating people to understand what the nature of marriage is and providing them with ongoing help and counselling. Let us get serious about fixing divorce and then we will be addressing one of the fundamental causes of youth suicide. There is no doubt that children suffer from divorce. The trendy view in recent years has been that a good divorce is better than a bad marriage, that kids are okay and that it is a bit like influenza: they will cough and splutter for a few days and then get on with their lives. But the fact is that they do not. Kids suffer from divorce. They suffer not just for a short period of time: the evidence I have seen indicates that they suffer for the rest of their lives. Their children are also likely to suffer because of the impact the divorce has had on their parents. It goes through a number of generations. Kids are hurt by divorce, and ultimately that is what will lead, in some cases, to kids becoming so desperate that they will want to end their agony by unfortunately taking their own lives. 9172 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 I thought this particular report was useful because it reinforces our understanding of the connection between divorce and youth suicide. I want to make a plea for us to get serious about fixing up the fundamental problem rather than thinking that we should spend more money on all of these other things. As worthwhile as they may appear to be, they will not solve the problem. It is interesting that we are very keen to stop people smoking because we realise smoking is a health hazard. I make the point very clearly that divorce is a health hazard for our kids. It also makes life harsher for our kids. Kids these days, I think, have a much harsher childhood than perhaps kids of my generation did. Our parents, as I recall, looking back at my own childhood, may not have got on terribly well the whole time but, in the end, they were very good parents and they stayed together till death parted them. I think we have benefited enormously from that. Kids today, faced with divorce rates of the magnitude that we are talking about, are faced with a very much harsher and more difficult childhood, and that, as we recognise, may lead to an increase in the rate of youth suicide. I recently read a book by David Blankenhorn, who visited Australia recently, called Fatherless America. While Mr Blankenhorn was here he did a number of interviews during which he talked about America and the importance of fathers to young men. Of course, divorce very often separates boys from their fathers, and we understand the reason for that happening. Mr Blankenhorn said that over 40 per cent of America's children do not live with their fathers, and I suspect that those sorts of percentages are almost being reached in Australia. Before they reach the age of 18, more than half of our nation's children will spend at least some of their childhood growing up without a father in their home. Nearly half of all children living apart from their fathers have not seen them in the previous year. More than 30 per cent of all children today are born to unmarried women. (Time expired) Corio( Mr O'Connor) of the opportunity to make a contribution I briefly want to respond to the very correct observation by the member for Isaacs( Mr Wilton). He quite rightly asked: 'Why is so much of the focus of this report on youth suicide?' The answer is that it was the first initiative of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. However, I would like to advise him, and all members, that as recently as last Friday, in this very chamber, we had a seminar on men's health. I assure the member for Isaacs that, very clearly, the overwhelming evidence collected will show that-the Hansard will be available as soon as it is approved-adult male suicide is very much a men's health problem, which was his quite correct observation. I am very pleased with the activities of the committee and we are very hopeful that shortly we will be able to present, on the table, a report in respect of that particular activity. With the environment of the competitive edge and economic pressures, males are suffering very much from this serious issue, and the member for Isaacs was quite correct to raise his concern. I assure him that it will be addressed. Mr O'CONNOR (Corio) (12.55 p.m.)-I congratulate the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs for this initiative and for the excellent report it has produced, Aspects of youth suiCide. Some of the committee's members are in the chamber today. In looking through this report I was reminded once again of the staggering statistics that it represents. This is a major social problem in this country, and it must be
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Forrest (Mallee) (12.53 P.m.)
theText: by leave-Not wanting to cheat the member forThursday, 2 October 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 9173 attacked not only by state and federal governments but by the community generally. The community is aware of it and is tackling it, certainly in my electorate. Some of the statistics just staggered me, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the statistics quoted here, in 1995 there were 350 suicides by young males and 84 by young females. That is a staggering loss to this nation if that particular statistic is repeated over time. Rates of suicide per 100,000 of population show that since the 1960s, the rate of young male suicides has almost trebled, and for young males in Australia between 1979 and 1995 there has been a fivefold increase in deaths arising from hanging. They are extraordinary statistics, and the report quite correctly homes in on the fact that this problem is endemic in rural and regional areas. In my particular state we reflect the statistics that are contained in this report. Suicide rates for males have increased dramatically in Victoria, ftom 5.6 per 100,000 in 1964 to 22.9 per 100,000 in 1995. That is an appalling and staggeting increase. While deaths by suicide are most common among males; suicide attempts are most common among women. Here we must look to the causes of this situation-not only why many young people are attempting suicide, but why it is that many females attempt but do not go through with the act, while many males do it and lose their lives. I guess many in this house have had experience of suicide and youth suicide. I go back to my time before entering this parliament. When I returned to the farm on the death of my father . in 1979 I was asked by a local Catholic. school to teach part time while I was working on the farm. I spent a lot of time with young people over quite a long period, and I can vividly recall one particular example of a young man who, to all intents and purposes, as the honourable member for Hunter( Mr Fitzgibbon) expressed in his contribution here, had the world at his feet. He was a runner and a bit of a goer and I, along with some other people in the school, spent a lot of time keeping him out of the principal's office. . He was a fine young man who, I would have thought, had he been able to make it through a particular period of his life, would have gone on to be a productive member of his local community and the Australian community. He had a very supportive family and he was much loved by that family. But at the end of the day, for reasons that we will never know, that young man took his own life. That is an experience that many of us on the floor of this parliament have been intimately acquainted with and have had contact with. In a very personal sense, it rocked me to my foundations, and made me aware of the tremendous trauma that is visited not only on families but on school communities and local communities by youth suicide. Many people have canvassed the reasons, and this report does that. We can go through those. They are many and varied. The honourable member for McPherson( Mr Bradford), who preceded me, quite correctly pointed out that some are within the ambit of government and some are not. I think we have to look primarily at the economic hardship of families and unemployment. That is concentrated fairly substantially in regional areas of this country. That is a major contributing factor. Families in distress are families that are prone to have members commit suicide. Other factors, as I read the literature, have been advanced: the loss of a sense of community, homelessness, depression, sexual assault, drugs, family conflict and decline in government support services. All of these factors have been mentioned as contributing factors to suicide, particularly youth suicide, in this country. 9174 MAIN COMMTITEE Thursday, 2 October 1997 The Geelong community is aware of this problem. There was a meeting in Geelong on 5 March 1997, which was attended by around 90 people, to deal specifically with this problem. The meeting was convened by the Victorian Premier's Suicide Prevention Task ForcandI commend politicians of any political persuasion who show an active interest in this subject. The message from that meeting was not one, I think, the Victorian Premier would want to hear, because speaker after speaker, of all political persuasions,condemned governments for the massive cutbacks in services that have occurred in rural areas particularly. They sheeted that home as a contributing factor to suicide in rural areas. I do not think we can just narrow that factor down. The honourable member who preceded me in this debate said that we are perhaps treating this matter after the fact. He made the point that money was not the solution to the problem and he quoted the financial contributions of the previous government and this government jn . addressing this problem. Maybe it is not so much in the $19 million that this government has allocated, or the $13 million that the previous government allocated, to address this problem but, in a broader sense, the responsibility of government to resource services in rural and regional areas t-at is able to play a role in combating this insidious disease. I want to very briefly comment on the Victoria task force report. When it delivered its report it identified the Barwon adolescent task force-BAT force-in my electorate as one of two bodies in the state which was providing a coordinated response to youth problems and addressing this issue. In my electorate in the Barwon region, the number of youth suicides is well below the Victorian state average. I congratulate BAT force, its committee of management and its network of concerned officers and agencies for their untiring work on behalf of youth in my electorate. It is the BAT force network which has delivered the real support to our youth, which has directly contributed to the situation which was acknowledged in the Victorian government's report. What was the solution? Why has this organisation been so effective? The chair, Ms Armstrong Rowe, had this to say: BAT force has built up strong community networks, good communications between agencies and it has well resourced the youth programs that are provided. I suggest to honourable members that if we are looking to part of the solution to this problem, it includes all the ones that have been mentioned in the report and by honourable members previously. Part of the solution is correctly resourcing in a financial sense these sorts of organisations that are able to deliver to youth the network of support services that can address some of the real and fundamental problems that youth face before youth go to the point of taking their own lives. I commend this report to all members of parliament and I congratulate those members who have participated in its preparation. Debate (on motion by Mr Vaile) adjourned. Main Committee adjourned at 1.06 p.m. The following answers to questions were circulated: (Question No. 2130) able member's question is as follows: Mr Mossfield asked the Minister for Yes. Australia has only one agreement which is Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon with the Government of Cuba. The agreement is in the form of a Memorandum of Understanding notice, on 25 August 1997: (MOU) on Migration Related Issues and was Does Australia have arrangements or agreements concluded on 24 September 1991. This MOU with other countries with respect to the deportation provides for the provision of travel documents and of persons from Australia who are convicted of deportation of persons from Australia to Cuba. criminal offences; if so, what.
title: Representatives Main Committee
